docs.title: Chowda
docs.text: A CLAMS processing app

docs.title: Install
docs.text: Install instructions can be found on the install page

docs.title: Reference
docs.text: Further details can be found in the reference section

docs.title: Credits
docs.text: Created by WGBH-MLA for the CLAMS project

docs.title: Clone the repository::
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/WGBH-MLA/chowda.git
cd chowda

docs.title: Install with PDM (Recommended)
docs.text:
PDM is used as the packaging manager. It can be installed with pip install pdm.

Install the project with development dependencies:

pdm install

Activate your virtual environment

$(pdm venv activate)

Note: pdm venv activate outputs the command needed to activate your virtual environment. The $() wrapper evaluates it in your current shell context.

docs.title: Install with venv
docs.text:
If PDM is not available, it can also be installed with pip. It is recommeneded to install to a virtual environment using venv:

python3 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate

Install the package

pip install .

docs.title: Run the application
docs.text:
uvicorn chowda:app --reload

Visit: localhost:8000

docs.title: Seed the database
docs.text:
To seed the database with fake data, run the seeds.py script:

python tests/seeds.py

Optional: Customize the number of records created by changing the num_* variables in the seed function.

docs.title: Deactivate the virtual environment
docs.text:
Run the deactivate command to return to your normal shell environment.

deactivate

docs.title: Ingest
docs.text:
In [ ]: Copied! 
from sonyci import SonyCi
from sonyci.log import log
from os import environ

# environ['DB_URL'] = 'sqlite:///../../chowda.development.sqlite'
from tests.factories import MediaFileFactory

log.remove()
ci = SonyCi.load_from_toml('../../ci.toml')
from sonyci import SonyCi from sonyci.log import log from os import environ # environ['DB_URL'] = 'sqlite:///../../chowda.development.sqlite' from tests.factories import MediaFileFactory log.remove() ci = SonyCi.load_from_toml('../../ci.toml') In [ ]: Copied! 
count = ci.get(f'workspaces/{ci.workspace_id}/contents?kind=asset&limit=1')['count']
count
count = ci.get(f'workspaces/{ci.workspace_id}/contents?kind=asset&limit=1')['count'] count In [ ]: Copied! 
def get_batch(n):
    return ci.get(
        f'workspaces/{ci.workspace_id}/contents?kind=asset&limit=100&fields=id,name,type,size,thumbnails,format&offset={n*100}'
    )['items']


# get_batch(0)
def get_batch(n): return ci.get( f'workspaces/{ci.workspace_id}/contents?kind=asset&limit=100&fields=id,name,type,size,thumbnails,format&offset={n*100}' )['items'] # get_batch(0) In [ ]: Copied! 
def ingest():
    for i in range(count // 100 + 1):
        for asset in get_batch(i):
            MediaFileFactory.create(id=asset['id'], guid=asset['name'])
def ingest(): for i in range(count // 100 + 1): for asset in get_batch(i): MediaFileFactory.create(id=asset['id'], guid=asset['name'])

ingest() took 68 minutes to ingest 174,170 guids!

42 guids/second

In [ ]: Copied! 
from sqlmodel import Session

from chowda.models import SonyCiAsset
from chowda.db import engine


def batch_ingest_session(n):
    with Session(engine) as session:
        batch = get_batch(n)
        # batch = [{**m, 'thumbnails': {'thumbnails': m['thumbnails']}} for m in batch]
        media = [SonyCiAsset(**asset) for asset in batch]
        session.add_all(media)
        session.commit()


# batch_ingest_session(11)
from sqlmodel import Session from chowda.models import SonyCiAsset from chowda.db import engine def batch_ingest_session(n): with Session(engine) as session: batch = get_batch(n) # batch = [{**m, 'thumbnails': {'thumbnails': m['thumbnails']}} for m in batch] media = [SonyCiAsset(**asset) for asset in batch] session.add_all(media) session.commit() # batch_ingest_session(11)

Each call currently happens in series, so we can use multiprocessing to parallelize the ingestion process.

In [ ]: Copied! 
from multiprocessing.pool import ThreadPool


def batch_ingest_with_threadpool():
    with ThreadPool() as pool:
        for _ in pool.map(batch_ingest_session, range(count // 100 + 1)):
            pass
from multiprocessing.pool import ThreadPool def batch_ingest_with_threadpool(): with ThreadPool() as pool: for _ in pool.map(batch_ingest_session, range(count // 100 + 1)): pass

11 minutes!

That's a 6x speedup!

264 guids/second

In [ ]: Copied! 
def batch_ingest_with_threadpool():
    with ThreadPool(32) as pool:
        for _ in pool.map(batch_ingest_session, range(count // 100 + 1)):
            pass
def batch_ingest_with_threadpool(): with ThreadPool(32) as pool: for _ in pool.map(batch_ingest_session, range(count // 100 + 1)): pass

docs.title: Ingest¶
docs.text: Ingest all guids from AAPB into Chowda

docs.title: But we can do better!¶
docs.text: First, we'll group the MediaFiles so we can add them in a single database commit.

docs.title: But we can do even better!¶
docs.text: Since this operation is network bound, we can use more processes than we have cores.

docs.title: Fastest!¶
docs.text:
1m 49s!

That's a 37x speedup!

1600 guids/second!!!

docs.title: SQLModel Session exercise
docs.text:
In [1]: Copied! 
from tests.factories import *
from tests.factories import * In [2]: Copied! 
batch = BatchFactory.create()
batch = BatchFactory.create() In [3]: Copied! 
from sqlmodel import Session

session = Session.object_session(batch)
from sqlmodel import Session session = Session.object_session(batch) In [4]: Copied! 
batch.description = "exceedingly jolly"
batch.description = "exceedingly jolly" In [5]: Copied! 
print('session.dirty = ', session.dirty)
# => session.dirty = IdentitySet([Batch(description='foo')])
print('session.dirty = ', session.dirty) # => session.dirty = IdentitySet([Batch(description='foo')]) 
session.dirty =  IdentitySet([Batch(description='exceedingly jolly')])
In [6]: Copied! 
session.commit()
session.commit() In [7]: Copied! 
print('session.dirty = ', session.dirty)
# => IdentitySet([])
print('session.dirty = ', session.dirty) # => IdentitySet([]) 
session.dirty =  IdentitySet([])
In [19]: Copied! 
from sqlmodel import select

with Session(engine) as db:
    batch_copy = db.exec(select(Batch).where(Batch.id == batch.id)).first()
print('batch_copy.description = ', batch_copy.description)
# => foo
from sqlmodel import select with Session(engine) as db: batch_copy = db.exec(select(Batch).where(Batch.id == batch.id)).first() print('batch_copy.description = ', batch_copy.description) # => foo 
batch_copy.description =  exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming and elaborately loquacious

Note that since we grabbed batch_copy using a contextual session, and that context has ended, so has the session, and the object is currently unattached to any session.

In [20]: Copied! 
print('seesion for batch_copy = ', Session.object_session(batch_copy))
# => None
print('seesion for batch_copy = ', Session.object_session(batch_copy)) # => None 
seesion for batch_copy =  None
In [12]: Copied! 
batch_copy.description += " and effortlessly charming"
with Session(engine) as db:
    db.add(batch_copy)
    db.commit()
batch_copy.description += " and effortlessly charming" with Session(engine) as db: db.add(batch_copy) db.commit() In [13]: Copied! 
with Session(engine) as db:
    db.add(batch_copy)
    print('batch_copy.description = ', batch_copy.description)
    # => batch_copy.description =  exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming
with Session(engine) as db: db.add(batch_copy) print('batch_copy.description = ', batch_copy.description) # => batch_copy.description = exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming 
batch_copy.description =  exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming
In [14]: Copied! 
print('batch.description before refresh = ', batch.description)
# => batch.description before refresh = exceedingly jolly
print('batch.description before refresh = ', batch.description) # => batch.description before refresh = exceedingly jolly 
batch.description before refresh =  exceedingly jolly
In [15]: Copied! 
session.refresh(batch)
print('batch.description after refresh = ', batch.description)
# => batch.description after refresh = exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming
session.refresh(batch) print('batch.description after refresh = ', batch.description) # => batch.description after refresh = exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming 
batch.description after refresh =  exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming
In [16]: Copied! 
batch.description += " and fantastically flatulent"
batch.description += " and fantastically flatulent" In [17]: Copied! 
session.commit()
session.commit() In [18]: Copied! 
with Session(engine) as db:
    batch_copy.description += " and elaborately loquacious"
    db.add(batch_copy)
    db.commit()
    print('batch_copy.description = ', batch_copy.description)
# => batch_copy.description =  exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming and elaborately loquacious
with Session(engine) as db: batch_copy.description += " and elaborately loquacious" db.add(batch_copy) db.commit() print('batch_copy.description = ', batch_copy.description) # => batch_copy.description = exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming and elaborately loquacious 
batch_copy.description =  exceedingly jolly and effortlessly charming and elaborately loquacious

docs.title: SQLModel Session exercise¶
docs.text: Adapted from Drew's slack example

docs.title: Create a new Batch from factory¶
Grab the session the Batch was created with for inspection.¶
View the changes that have yet to be committed to the db¶
Commit the changes to the db.¶
docs.text: Note that we do not have to call session.add(batch) since the Batch instance is already attached to the session.

docs.title: Verify there are no other pending changes.¶
Use a contextual session¶
docs.text: (called "db") to grab a separate copy of the batch and verify it has the change.

docs.title: Now change batch_copy.descripiton,¶
docs.text: save it with a contextual session, and see how it affected or original Batch instance, which is still alive and attached to the session it was created with.

docs.title: NOTE: after committing changes to batch_copy using contextual session in this way,¶
docs.text:
trying to access attributes on the object like batch_copy.description raises an error:

Instance <Batch at 0x107b84e10> is not bound to a Session; attribute refresh operation cannot proceed

docs.title: Confirm that our original Batch instance still has the old description¶
Refresh the original Batch instance¶
docs.text: and check the description again

docs.title: Now let's edit batch.description and batch_copy.description¶
docs.text: and update them both independently to see what happens.

docs.title: Unsurprisingly, the 2nd save wins.¶
docs.text: The changes saved in original Batch instance with it's original session get overwritten by this one.

docs.title: MediaUrl = stricturl(allowed_schemes=['video', 'audio', 'text'], tld_required=False) module-attribute
docs.text:
Media url validator. Must have prefix of video, audio, or text. No TLD required.

Example

video://*

docs.title: MediaFile
docs.text:
Bases: SQLModel

Media file model

Attributes:

Name Type Description id Optional[int]

SonyCi asset id

guid str

asset guid

Source code in chowda/models.py 
class MediaFile(SQLModel, table=True):
"""Media file model

    Attributes:
        id: SonyCi asset id
        guid: asset guid
    """

    __tablename__ = 'media_files'
    id: Optional[int] = Field(primary_key=True, default=None)
    guid: str = Field(index=True)
    mmif_json: Dict[str, Any] = Field(sa_column=Column(JSON), default=None)
    collections: List['Collection'] = Relationship(
        back_populates='media_files', link_model=MediaFileCollectionLink
    )
    batches: List['Batch'] = Relationship(
        back_populates='media_files', link_model=MediaFileBatchLink
    )
    clams_events: List['ClamsEvent'] = Relationship(back_populates='media_file')

    async def __admin_repr__(self, request: Request):
        return self.guid

    async def __admin_select2_repr__(self, request: Request) -> str:
        return f'<span><strong>{self.guid}</strong></span>'

docs.title: User
docs.text:
Bases: SQLModel

User model

Attributes:

Name Type Description id Optional[int]

Primary key

email EmailStr

User email

first_name str

User first name

last_name str

User last name

Source code in chowda/models.py 
class User(SQLModel, table=True):
"""User model

    Attributes:
        id: Primary key
        email: User email
        first_name: User first name
        last_name: User last name
    """

    __tablename__ = 'users'
    id: Optional[int] = Field(primary_key=True)
    email: EmailStr = Field(index=True)
    first_name: str = Field(min_length=3, index=True)
    last_name: str = Field(min_length=3, index=True)

    async def __admin_repr__(self, request: Request):
        return f'{self.first_name} {self.last_name}'
